page.title: 03Churches in the Area.
page.content: There has been a church in Hornby since at least the 12th. Century. The Parish Church of St. Margaret of Antioch possesses a rare octagonal tower which was built in 1513 by Lord Monteagle. The church possesses a "Loaves and Fishes" Cross which is over 1000 years old and is the only one in this country. The church also has an altar front and vestments on display which are of Italian origin. Across the road is the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary's which can seat no more than 15 or so. Across the valley, at St. John's Church in Gressingham there is the sculptured remains of a pre Norman cross. The nave is separated from the chancel by a pointed arch and a Norman style tower arch soars over the font. St. John's dates from the 13th. Century.
